creditline: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Hodroff
description: white with underglaze blue decor; Qianlong four-character seal mark and period two mushroom rim caps, loop handle and three flaring tall legs painted with band of flying cranes below rim and repeated around well of base; molded with three peaks at center to support Jue on short four-footed stand
text: The shape of this tripodal vessel, called <I>ch√ºeh<I>, derives from ancient Shang dynasty (12th-11th century B.C.) ritual bronzes. Those bronzes were used for the ceremonial heating and drinking of wine. But this cup and stand probably served as a small water container or brush washer. Although blue-and-white porcelain is more decorative than "organic taste" scholar's objects, the reference here to China's antiquity and illustrious Bronze Age would have made this piece acceptable to 18th-century literati.
title: Tripod Vessel with Stand
